subject: RE: [junit] Proposed parameterized test syntax for JUnit 4

messageBody:
Elliotte,

Parameterized tests violate an assumption in JUnit that some of which JUnit GUIs depend on, that tests can be uniquely identified by a class and method name. However, I can see that they are potentially useful. One question is whether to add functionality to JUnit only at a speed the test runners can match or march ahead, accepting that temporarily-poor GUI support is the price of architectural progress. Having not changed JUnit much in years, I am ready to move forward.

Here is a revised parameterized test proposal for comment. Three things have changed.
* The class is now annotated with a class used to run it: @Factory(Parameterized.class). This seems like a very general mechanism to me. For example, I was able to write a test runnerlet to run JUnit 3.x AllTests in a few minutes. Would JUnit extenders find this annotation generally helpful?
* The data comes from a static method instead of a static field. A method seemed more general than a field and is evaluated later, when the test is run instead of when the class is loaded. Totally static data can be simply implemented by a method which just returns that data.
* Parameters are passed to a constructor instead of stuffed into fields. This seems more general as well as reducing the number of annotations by one. One limitation of the current implementation is that parameterized test classes can only have a single constructor.

Here is an example:
@Factory(Parameterized.class) //TODO This shouldn't be called Factory, because it doesn't create anything. "Runner", perhaps?
public class FibonacciTest {
@Parameters public static Object[] data() {
return new int[][] {{0, 0}, {1, 1}, {2, 1}, {3, 2}, {4, 3}, {5, 5}, {6, 8}};
}

private int input;
private int expected;

public FibonacciTest(int input, int expected) {
this.input= input;
this.expected= expected;
}

@Test public void test() {
assertEquals(expected, fib(input));
}

private int fib(int x) {
return 0;
}
}

Comments?

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> What would the output from this be? i.e. what does it look
> like when the
> test fails? Can I easily tell with which parameter it's breaking? and
> can I easily debug just that case?
>
> One of the things I like about the current JUnit 3 non-parameterized
> approach is that when something does fail, I can immediately
> reproduce
> it to step through in a debugger. I have occasionally done something
> similar to this mechanism without using generics simply by having an
> array of parameters and a for loop inside the test method.
> That's great
> as long as everything's passing, but it's much less convenient when
> something fails.
